result.execSummary:
The defendant Alec J Brazeau was found guilty of the following charge(s) in this case.

  • Criminal Damage to Property (Over $2500) [Modifiers: PTAC, as a Party to a Crime], a class I felony, Wisconsin Statutes 943.01(2)(d).
  • Entry into/onto Bldg/Constuct.Site/Room [Modifiers: PTAC, as a Party to a Crime], a class A misdemeanor, Wisconsin Statutes 943.15(1).

Charge(s) in this case were read in to this or other case(s). A "read in" charge is a charge that is dismissed as part of a plea agreement, however:

  • The defendant agrees to have the court consider the charge(s) when sentencing for another crime, under Wis. Stats. 973.20(1g)(b); and
  • The defendant cannot be prosecuted for these charge(s) in the future.

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.

supervisions.notes:
STAYED.
IF REVOKED: Defendant IS eligible for Challenge Incarceration Program.
Defendant IS NOT eligible for Substance Abuse Program.

miscConds.notes:
BAIL APPLIED TO COSTS. Balance of $18.00 to be paid as a Condition of Probation.

If probation is revoked and a prison term is not ordered, or if probation is discharged/terminated, a civil judgment shall be entered against the defendant and in favor of restitution victims and government entities for outstanding financial obligations.  Collection may include income assignment.
Maintain full time employment and/or school.
Submit to an AODA Assessment and follow through with any treatment recommended.

It is the Defendant's burden to petition the Court to receive the benefit of expunction. Expunction is conditionally granted upon verification of completion of sentence, payment of all costs/fees/restitution and no new criminal law violations.

Maintain absolute sobriety.
Submit to random alcohol/drug screens.
Not to use or possess of alcohol or controlled substances without a valid prescription or any drug paraphernalia.
Any valid prescription drugs must be taken only in the manner in which they are prescribed.
Inform Agent of all prescriptions.
Follow through with any treatment/counseling recommended.
Provide DNA Sample if not already provided.
No contact with Wales Elementary, Wales Elementary personnel and/or Co-actors.

Cases 16CF701 and 16CF635 were both dismissed and read into: 15CF1192.

Restitution to be determined.

AS OF 3/10/2017:  $67,255.42 to be added to the previous restitution. $47,107.89 made payable to CHUBB for reimbursement and $20,147.53 made payable to Kettle Moraine School District. To be paid joint and several. As a condition of Probation.

  If Probation/Extended Supervision is revoked and/or a prison term ordered, outstanding financial obligations shall be collected pursuant to statutory provisions, including deductions from inmate prison monies.  If discharged with outstanding financial obligations, a civil judgment shall be entered against the defendant and in favor of restitution victims and government entities for outstanding financial obligations.  Collections may include income assignment.

timeConds.notes: Condition Time - STAYED. To be used at Agent's discretion as well as to the huber or straight time.
Perform 40 hours per EACH YEAR of probation.

records.addlTxt: Exhibits #11-13 from 3/10/17 restitution hearing
Continuation and Stipulation for Return/Destruction of Exhibits

Attorney Kristi Nelson Foy appeared on behalf of victim Kettle Moraine School District.  Attorney Steven Harvey appeared on behalf of Chubb Insurance.   Defendant Alec J Brazeau in court, in custody, with attorney Matthew H Huppertz.  Defendant Ian T Anderson in court with attorney Marcella De Peters.  Defendant Jacob W Lange in court, in custody, with attorney John Joseph Grau.

Attorney Havey presents Exhibit #11, marked.  Attorney Foy advises the parties have reached a stipulation as to some of the restitution amounts.  

Dr. Patricia Deklotz, Superintendent of the Kettle Moraine School District, sworn in and examined by Attorney Foy.  Cross-examination by Attorney Grau.  Cross-examination by Attorney Huppertz.  Cross-examination by Attorney De Peters.  Cross-examination by Attorney Harvey.  

Dale Zabel, Director of Facility Services and Safety for the Kettle Moraine School District, sworn in and examined by Attorney Foy.  Cross-examination by Attorney Grau.  Cross-examination by Attorney De Peters.  

Exhibits #1 - 10, previously presented by Attorney Foy and marked, are received.  Attorney Foy presents Exhibit #12, marked and received.  Exhibit #11 is received.  No objection from any of the parties.  

Attorney Grau presents Exhibit #13, marked and received.  No objection from any of the parties.  

Alec Brazeau sworn in and examined by Attorney Huppertz.  Cross-examination by Attorney Harvey.  Court closes the evidentiary portion of the hearing.

Attorney Foy advises Court of stipulated amounts and amounts still in dispute.  Attorney Foy makes argument for restitution.   Attorney Harvey makes statement.  Attorney De Peters makes statement.  Attorney Huppertz makes statement.  Attorney Grau makes statement.  Attorney Foy makes final argument.  

Court finds that the request for reimbursement for security guards, security cameras, missing Mac book, reimbursement to Chubb Insurance and copying costs as reasonable.  Court denies the request for attorney fees.  
Court orders restitution, joint and several, as follows:

$47,107.89 made payable to CHUBB for reimbursement
$20,147.53 made payable to Kettle Moraine School District
